questions.text: A previously healthy 12-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of abdominal pain and vomiting. His mother states that over the past 6 hours he has been having intermittent episodes of inconsolable crying, during which he “grabs his abdomen and draws up his legs.” These episodes have been accompanied by nonbloody, nonbilious vomiting and reddish, mucoid bowel movements. He appears sleepy. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. He cries when his abdomen is palpated. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count shows a leukocyte count of 12,000/mm3. Serum electrolyte levels are within normal limits. An abdominal x-ray shows no free air. Abdominal ultrasonography is shown. Intravenous fluid resuscitation with normal saline is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Therapy with ampicillin, tobramycin, and metronidazole

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The Ladd procedure is the standard treatment for intestinal malrotation with volvulus, which typically manifests during the first year of life with bilious vomiting, constant abdominal pain and distention, and signs of bowel ischemia (e.g., rectal bleeding, shock). Abdominal x-ray may show the double bubble sign, although x-ray is primarily used to exclude bowel perforation. Abdominal ultrasound, although not routinely performed, may show a whirlpool sign rather than the target sign seen here.

B) CORRECT:

Air enema is the treatment of choice for intussusception. This procedure creates pressure within the intestine and pushes the bowel back into its normal position. Hydrostatic enema is a viable alternative (the mechanism is the same, only normal saline is used instead of air). After the procedure, the patient should be monitored for 4 hours, because intussusception often recurs during that time frame.
Image Description:

A proximal part of the bowel invaginates into a distal part → congestion of mesenteric vessels → edema, ischemia → necrosis, perforation

C) INCORRECT:

Appendectomy is the treatment of choice in acute appendicitis, which occurs rarely in the first year of life. Acute appendicitis may manifest with fever, vomiting, irritability, diarrhea, and tenderness and guarding of the abdomen. Ultrasound in appendicitis typically shows a dilated appendix with edematous walls. Appendicitis can mimic the target sign appearance of intussusception, especially in axial views, and if the appendix is already perforated. On longitudinal views, it is usually possible to differentiate intussusception and appendicitis, because the appendix is a blind-ending sac. Additionally, in axial views, the appendiceal lumen is usually filled with hypoechogenic fluid or debris, whereas the typical finding in intussusception is alternating echogenicity due to intussuscepted bowel mucosa.

D) INCORRECT:

Technetium-99m pertechnetate scan is used to diagnose symptomatic Meckel diverticulum, which may cause complications such as ulceration, hemorrhage, intussusception, and intestinal obstruction in children. The majority of patients are asymptomatic, but if symptoms are present, hematochezia is the most common. The intussusception diagnosed in this child, especially in light of the reddish bowel movements, could indeed be the result of a Meckel diverticulum. However, regardless of the etiology of the intussusception, treatment needs to be initiated quickly and should not be delayed by further diagnostic studies.

E) INCORRECT:

Pyloromyotomy is the standard treatment for infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS), which can manifest with nonbilious vomiting. However, an upper abdominal mass is commonly found. Furthermore, IHPS rarely manifests after 12 weeks of age, so it is an unlikely diagnosis in this 12-month-old boy.

F) INCORRECT:

Flexible sigmoidoscopy is used in children with abdominal pain and/or chronic diarrhea when a diagnosis is unclear. However, this patient's clinical presentation and ultrasound findings indicate intussusception, so another step in management is more appropriate at this point.

G) INCORRECT:

The combination of ampicillin, tobramycin, and metronidazole is used to treat necrotizing enterocolitis, which causes feeding intolerance, abdominal distension, and bloody stools, most commonly in premature newborns. Pneumatosis intestinalis is a common sign on abdominal x-ray. This patient has none of these clinical features, does not have radiographic signs of pneumatosis intestinalis, and is not a premature newborn.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a premature neonate

Multiple loops of gas-filled bowel are seen, some of which are accompanied by linear (example indicated by red arrowhead) and bubbly (examples indicated by green arrowheads) lucencies that indicate intramural gas (pneumatosis intestinalis; areas in green circles). Subtle linear lucencies (examples indicated by black arrowheads) projecting over the right upper quadrant might indicate portal venous gas. There is no pneumoperitoneum.

An NG tube (yellow overlay) terminates in the stomach.
questions.hint: Colicky abdominal pain, nonbilious vomiting, reddish mucoid stools (currant jelly stools), and target sign on ultrasonography are consistent with intussusception, which has a peak incidence in infants 3 to 12 months of age.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with acute intermittent umbilical pain that began that morning. The pain radiates to his right lower abdomen and occurs every 15–30 minutes. During these episodes of pain, the boy draws up his knees to the chest. The patient has had several episodes of nonbilious vomiting. He had a similar episode 3 months ago. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.86°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows periumbilical tenderness with no masses palpated. Laboratory studies show:


Leukocyte count
8,000/mm3



Hemoglobin
10.6 g/dL


Hematocrit
32%


Platelet count
180,000/mm3



Serum



Sodium
143 mEq/L


Potassium
3.7 mEq/L


Chloride
88 mEq/L


Bicarbonate
28 mEq/L


Urea nitrogen
19 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.3 mg/dL


Abdominal ultrasound shows concentric rings of bowel in transverse view. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intestinal adhesions may cause bowel obstruction or act as a pathological lead point for intussusception. They usually form after previous abdominal surgery, intraabdominal inflammation, or abdominal radiotherapy, none of which is mentioned in this patient's history.

B) CORRECT:

Recurrent episodes of intussusception should raise concern for a pathological lead point. Intussusception due to a pathological lead point should always be suspected in children > 5 years or < 3 months of age, whereas idiopathic intussusception (i.e., without an identifiable lead point) most commonly occurs in children 3 months to 5 years of age. Meckel diverticulum is the pathological lead point that most commonly causes intussusception. Meckel diverticulum may contain ectopic gastric mucosal cells that secrete gastric acid and thereby lead to irritation and ulceration of the adjacent small bowel, which can cause occult gastrointestinal bleeding and anemia.

A technetium-99m pertechnetate scan can be used to diagnose Meckel diverticulum.
Image Description:

Ultrasound abdomen (bowel; transverse plane)

Concentric alternating hyperechoic and hypoechoic rings are visible. The hyperechoic rings (green overlay) are formed by mucosa and the hypoechoic rings (red overlay) by submucosa. Together the alternating layers produce a target-like appearance (target sign; bull's eye sign).

C) INCORRECT:

Acute appendicitis manifests with diffuse, continuous, abdominal pain migrating from the periumbilical region to the right lower quadrant, vomiting, and a “target sign” on ultrasound. However, repeated attacks of pain and the presence of anemia in this patient suggest a different diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Malrotation with volvulus typically manifests with acute onset of abdominal pain and bloody stools. On abdominal ultrasound, the classic feature of volvulus is a whirlpool sign (also known as “whirl sign”; referring to the twisted mesentery), which can easily be distinguished from the target sign described in this patient. Although the clinical features may be similar, a volvulus caused by malrotation of the intestines usually occurs during early infancy; it would be uncommon in a 6-year-old child.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (with oral and IV contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with sigmoid volvulus

A whirl of mesenteric vessels (red overlay) is seen in the pelvis in the setting of multiple dilated loops of obstructed large bowel.

The whirlpool sign (also known as whirl sign) can be seen when the colon rotates around its mesentery in sigmoid volvulus causing rotation of the mesenteric vessels. The sign is also seen in a number of other causes of volvulus and torsion, and is not specific for sigmoid volvulus.

Additional findings on the CT include gaseous distention of small bowel, retained material in the stomach, a left renal cyst, and aortoiliac calciications.

E) INCORRECT:

Intestinal polyps are the second most common pathological lead point resulting in intussusception. While intestinal polyps cannot be entirely excluded, they are not the most common cause of intussusception in this age group. This patient appears to have had chronic blood loss that resulted in anemia, suggesting a different etiology.
questions.hint: Acute onset of cyclical abdominal pain, vomiting, and a target sign on ultrasound is consistent with an episode of intussusception.

questions.text: An 11-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of intermittent episodes of inconsolable crying for 4 hours. The parents report that the patient does not appear to be in discomfort between episodes, and moves and plays normally. The episodes have occurred at roughly 15-minute intervals and have each lasted a few minutes before subsiding. He has also vomited 3 times since these episodes began. The first vomitus appeared to contain food while the second and third appeared pale green in color. The patient was born at term and has been healthy. His immunizations are up-to-date. He has no history of recent travel. His older brother has Crohn disease. The patient is at 50th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. He does not appear to be in acute distress. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 36/min, and blood pressure is 85/40 mm Hg. During the examination, the patient begins to cry and draws his knees up to his chest. Shortly thereafter, he passes stool with a mixture of blood and mucus; the patient's discomfort appears to resolve. Abdominal examination shows a sausage-shaped abdominal mass in the right upper quadrant. Abdominal ultrasound shows concentric rings of bowel in transverse view. Intravenous fluid resuscitation with normal saline is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the abdomen can be used to better visualize intraabdominal structures and masses, including possible tumors. Moreover, a CT scan may show a target sign and help identify pathological lead points in patients with intussusception. Although this patient has a palpable abdominal mass, his young age and acute onset of symptoms make an intraabdominal tumor an unlikely diagnosis. Moreover, a CT scan should only be performed in patients with suspected intussusception if the diagnosis is unclear and other diagnostic procedures are inconclusive because radiation exposure in children should be avoided whenever possible.

B) INCORRECT:

An exploratory laparotomy allows direct visualization of intraabdominal structures and is generally only indicated in certain cases of trauma or when other diagnostic modalities have failed. This patient has none of the traumatic indications needed for exploratory laparotomy and there are less invasive diagnostic methods available.

C) INCORRECT:

Abdominal x-ray in a patient with intussusception may reveal an inhomogeneous distribution of gas with absence of air at the site of invagination (usually right upper and lower quadrants). These x-ray findings are nonspecific and not helpful in establishing a definitive diagnosis. Also, radiation exposure in children should be avoided whenever possible.

D) INCORRECT:

An abdominal MRI can be used to better visualize intraabdominal structures or masses and possible tumors. Despite the exam findings, this patient's young age and acute onset of symptoms make an intraabdominal mass or tumor an unlikely diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

An image-guided air enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic for intussusception. An air enema or an enema with water-soluble contrast would show an interruption of contrast at the site of invagination and would likely reduce the intussusception.
Image Description:

Contrast enema; lateral view
Rectum and lower sigmoid are filled with contrast (dark); sudden interruption of contrast in the upper sigmoid (green area).
S = spine
LE = lower extremity
questions.hint: Acute cyclical abdominal pain with asymptomatic periods, vomiting (initially nonbilious), and currant jelly stool (composed of blood and mucus), together with a sausage-shaped mass in the right upper quadrant and target sign on abdominal ultrasound is consistent with intussusception. This condition is the most common cause of bowel obstruction in the first two years of life.

C) INCORRECT:

Intestinal adhesions may cause bowel obstruction or act as a pathologic lead point for intussusception. They usually form after abdominal surgery, intra-abdominal inflammation, or abdominal radiotherapy, none of which are mentioned in this patient's history.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute appendicitis manifests with diffuse, continuous abdominal pain migrating from the periumbilical region to the right lower quadrant, vomiting, and target sign on ultrasound, making it an important differential diagnosis for this patient's symptoms. However, repeated attacks of pain and the presence of anemia in this patient suggest a different diagnosis.
questions.hint: This 6-year-old boy presents with acute cyclical abdominal pain, with his knees drawn to the chest, nonbilious vomiting, and a target sign on ultrasound, which is a constellation of symptoms most consistent with intussusception. The recurrence of the episode and the presence of anemia are suggestive of a particular pathologic lead point.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department (ED) with one day of nonbilious, nonbloody vomiting that has been associated with intermittent, generalized abdominal pain and one episode of nonbloody, loose stool.
On initial examination, she appears generally well, at times playful, with only mild discomfort. She is afebrile, and her vital signs are normal for her age. Abdominal examination is benign.
Thirty minutes after arrival to the ED, she becomes irritable and begins screaming in pain. On repeat examination, she pulls up her legs against her chest and exhibits diffuse abdominal tenderness and guarding. An intravenous line is placed, and blood is drawn.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
8000
6000–17,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
12.0
11.5–13.5


Hematocrit (%)
36.1
34–40


Platelet count (per mm3)
320,000
150,000–450,000


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
19
5–45


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
21
13–35


Bilirubin, total (mg/dL)
0.7
<1.5


Lipase (U/liter)
20
3–32


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm/hour)
22
0–20


Sodium (mEq/liter)
136
135–147


Potassium (mEq/liter)
3.4
3.4–4.7


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
18
22–26


Urinalysis is normal. The patient's diaper has blood-tinged, loose stool.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Send stool for Shiga toxin enzyme immunoassay
Consult gastroenterology for urgent upper endoscopy
Obtain CT of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous and oral contrast
Administer a proton pump inhibitor intravenously

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infectious causes should be considered in cases of bloody diarrhea, and in those cases, stool culture and testing for Shiga toxin may be useful. However, an infectious etiology is less likely in this patient given her episodic, severe pain. The more likely diagnosis is intussusception.

B) INCORRECT:

An upper endoscopy might be considered if there is evidence of upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding. Although this patient had a positive stool test for occult blood, she is hemodynamically stable, has a normal complete blood count, and lacks clear signs of acute, upper GI bleeding such as hematemesis. Upper endoscopy is generally avoided when there is concern for an acute process requiring surgery (as in this patient); the test is reserved for evaluation of chronic symptoms that localize to the upper GI tract.

C) INCORRECT:

Other imaging modalities, such as abdominal CT, may be helpful in the diagnostic workup of acute abdominal pain. Conditions such as acute appendicitis, pancreatitis, renal disease, and hepatobiliary disease must be considered and can be evaluated by CT. However, this patient’s normal laboratory workup (complete blood count, lipase measurement, urinalysis, and liver function testing) renders those diagnoses less likely. Moreover, CT requires radiation, which is unnecessary if ultrasound is available.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation — particularly the intermittent nature of the abdominal pain — is most consistent with intussusception. Intussusception is a common cause of acute abdominal pain in young children and the leading cause of bowel obstruction in this age group. Because it is a surgical emergency, failure to promptly diagnose and treat it can result in poor outcomes. Intussusception is characterized by the telescoping of bowel onto adjacent bowel. Although it can be transient and self-resolving, persistence of this condition requires intervention, most commonly reduction via air enema. If air enema is unsuccessful on multiple attempts or if there are complications such as bowel perforation, emergency surgical intervention is indicated. Intussusception is most common in infants and toddlers, whose inability to characterize their symptoms might delay consideration of intussusception and complicate the diagnosis. Furthermore, the clinical presentation of intussusception is variable. The commonly described intussusception triad — colicky abdominal pain, a palpable abdominal mass, and bloody stools — is not always observed. Children <12 months of age are more likely to have grossly bloody stools than those aged 12 to 36 months of age, and the classic palpable abdominal mass is found in <40% of patients of all ages. Presentation of intussusception may also include nonspecific symptoms such as lethargy and altered level of consciousness. The most appropriate initial diagnostic test for intussusception is abdominal ultrasound, which has excellent sensitivity (98% –100%). Among experienced radiologists, a normal abdominal ultrasound can rule out intussusception. Ultrasound is relatively inexpensive, easily accessible, and does not involve radiation.

Key learning point: The best initial diagnostic modality for intussusception is abdominal ultrasound.

E) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are important in the management of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). In young children, GERD typically manifests with chronic symptoms of dyspepsia, dysphagia, regurgitation, or failure to thrive, rather than the acute symptoms this patient has. A PPI may serve as a supportive measure in the setting of acute illness, but it would be a slow-acting, insufficient intervention in this patient, who has severe symptoms and requires more-urgent investigation.

questions.text:
An 11-month-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department with a 2-day history of sudden, intense episodes of crying, drawing his knees to his chest, and bilious vomiting. His mother notes increasing lethargy between episodes. He appears dehydrated. Examination reveals a soft abdomen with a palpable spindle-shaped mass in the right upper quadrant.

Heart rate
150/min

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hirschsprung disease involves a congenital absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon, leading to chronic bowel obstruction, typically presenting in newborns or early infancy with persistent constipation and abdominal distension. The sudden, intermittent pain and bilious vomiting here suggest an acute obstruction, not the chronic motility disorder seen in Hirschsprung disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Pyloric stenosis typically presents in infants aged 3 to 6 weeks with progressive, nonbilious projectile vomiting due to gastric outlet obstruction. The 11-month-old infant's bilious vomiting indicates an obstruction beyond the bile entry point. Additionally, pyloric stenosis lacks the episodic, colicky pain seen here, and the palpable mass is not the typical 'olive' associated with pyloric stenosis.

C) CORRECT:

Intussusception manifests in infants, particularly those aged 6 to 36 months, with episodes of intense, colicky abdominal pain, during which they may draw their knees to the chest. Bilious vomiting indicates bowel obstruction, and the intermittent symptoms with lethargy suggest episodic pain relief between ischemic episodes. The palpable, spindle-shaped mass in the right upper quadrant corresponds to the telescoped bowel segment, a hallmark of intussusception. This condition involves a proximal bowel segment invaginating into a distal segment, leading to vascular compromise and inflammation, which explains the clinical presentation.

Key learning point: Intussusception in infants presents with intermittent abdominal pain, vomiting, lethargy, and a palpable abdominal mass, often in the right upper quadrant.

D) INCORRECT:

Midgut volvulus can cause bilious vomiting due to intestinal obstruction but usually presents with sudden, continuous severe abdominal pain and rapid clinical deterioration. It is more common in neonates or very young infants with congenital malrotation. The palpable, spindle-shaped mass is not characteristic of midgut volvulus.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department with 8 hours of intermittent, severe abdominal pain. He has had two episodes of vomiting, including one that was bile-stained, and his last stool contained traces of blood. During painful episodes, he draws his knees up and is quiet in between. A tender sausage-shaped mass is felt in the right upper quadrant.


Heart rate
130/min



Blood pressure
90/60 mm Hg


Temperature
38.1°C


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The presentation of episodic severe colicky abdominal pain, bilious vomiting, and blood-tinged stool in an infant suggests intussusception. The palpable 'sausage-shaped' mass in the right upper quadrant supports this diagnosis. Barium enema serves as both a diagnostic and therapeutic tool, using hydrostatic pressure to reduce the intussuscepted bowel segment. It is effective in children without signs of perforation or peritonitis, aligning with management strategies for pediatric intussusception.

Key learning point: In suspected intussusception in infants, a barium enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic, often resolving the obstruction non-surgically.

B) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) provides excellent soft tissue contrast but is impractical in acute settings due to long acquisition times and the need for sedation. In suspected gastrointestinal obstruction, rapid imaging is crucial. MRI's logistical challenges and the need for patient cooperation limit its utility in emergent pediatric scenarios.

C) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antibiotics are indicated for infections or cases with perforation and peritonitis. This patient's presentation suggests intussusception, an obstructive etiology, without evidence of sepsis or perforation. The low-grade fever may result from inflammation due to obstruction, not infection. The focus should be on diagnostic imaging and nonoperative reduction.

D) INCORRECT:

Immediate laparotomy is considered when there is bowel perforation, peritonitis, or significant hemodynamic instability. This patient has typical intussusception signs, such as a palpable mass and bilious vomiting, but lacks signs of perforation or peritonitis, such as a rigid abdomen or septic shock. Surgical intervention is reserved for cases where nonoperative management fails or complications arise.

questions.text:
A 16-month-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department by his parents with 6 hours of intermittent, severe abdominal pain. He periodically draws his legs up, cries loudly, then becomes very quiet and appears exhausted. His last stool was dark red. He is afebrile and exhibits moderate tachycardia. Examination reveals a palpable cylindrical mass in the right upper quadrant.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to identify the cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Plain abdominal radiographs can assess for bowel obstruction or perforation but have low sensitivity and specificity for intussusception. They may show indirect signs like a soft tissue mass but lack the ability to delineate bowel layers involved in telescoping. In this case, a more targeted imaging modality is needed to confirm intussusception.

B) INCORRECT:

An air contrast enema can diagnose and treat intussusception but is typically used after confirmation by noninvasive imaging. It carries risks such as perforation and is not the initial diagnostic step. Ultrasonography is preferred for initial evaluation due to its safety and effectiveness.

C) INCORRECT:

CT scans provide detailed imaging but involve significant radiation exposure, which is a concern in young children. They may require sedation, adding risk. In this case, ultrasonography is more appropriate due to its noninvasive nature and lack of radiation.

D) CORRECT:

Ultrasonography is the preferred initial diagnostic tool for intussusception due to its high sensitivity and specificity. It can reveal the classic target or doughnut sign, indicating telescoped bowel layers. This noninvasive method is ideal for pediatric patients, as it avoids radiation exposure and provides real-time visualization of bowel movement and mesenteric vessels. Ultrasonography effectively identifies the anatomical changes in intussusception, guiding further management.

Key learning point: In suspected intussusception in children, an abdominal ultrasound is the diagnostic method of choice due to its non-invasive nature and ability to effectively identify the condition.

questions.text:
A 10-month-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department with 6 hours of recurring severe abdominal pain, during which he draws up his knees and vomits. Between episodes, he appears fatigued. His most recent diaper contained stool streaked with blood. He is afebrile with stable vital signs. Examination reveals a firm, elongated mass in the right upper quadrant (see report).
Abdominal ultrasound: Distinctive target-like lesion
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Air enema reduction under imaging guidance

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While intravenous fluids are important for dehydration, this patient has stable vital signs and no significant dehydration. Intussusception requires prompt reduction of the telescoped bowel segment, typically with an air enema, to prevent ischemia and perforation.

B) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics are indicated for systemic infection, perforation, or bowel necrosis. This patient presents with a mechanical obstruction due to intussusception, not an infectious process. He is stable and shows no signs of sepsis or peritoneal irritation, so antibiotics are not appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Exploratory laparotomy is reserved for cases with complications such as perforation, peritonitis, or bowel necrosis. This patient is stable and afebrile, with no signs of these complications. Nonoperative reduction with an air enema is the preferred initial treatment for intussusception.

D) CORRECT:

Air enema reduction is the first-line treatment for intussusception in stable pediatric patients. Intussusception occurs when a segment of the intestine telescopes into an adjacent segment, often at the ileocecal junction, leading to ischemia. It presents with severe abdominal pain, a palpable mass, and bloody stools. Ultrasound typically shows a target sign. An air enema, performed under imaging guidance, introduces air into the colon to reduce the intussuscepted bowel segments, restoring normal intestinal continuity. This method is effective and safe in the absence of complications like perforation or peritonitis.

Key learning point: Intussusception in children is often treated successfully with non-surgical reduction using air or saline enemas under imaging guidance, which is preferred over surgical intervention in stable patients.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department with 6 hours of intermittent abdominal pain. His parents report that he has been pulling his knees to his chest and crying during episodes of pain. He has vomited twice, and his last stool had streaks of blood. He appears lethargic between painful episodes, and his abdomen is moderately distended.


Heart rate
130/min


Blood pressure
90/60 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
25/min


Temperature
37.8°C


Which of the following imaging studies is the most appropriate initial test?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abdominal CT scans provide detailed anatomical information but involve ionizing radiation, which is a concern in young children. CT scans often require sedation in toddlers, adding risk. They are not favored as initial tests when non-ionizing options like ultrasound are available for common pediatric conditions like intussusception.

B) CORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasound is the preferred initial diagnostic test for suspected intussusception in pediatric patients. It is non-invasive, avoids radiation, and provides rapid and accurate assessment. Ultrasound can identify the characteristic target or doughnut sign, indicating telescoped bowel segments. It also allows for real-time evaluation of complications such as free fluid, suggesting perforation or ischemia. The clinical presentation of intermittent abdominal pain, lethargy, and bloody stools aligns with intussusception, making ultrasound the diagnostic test of choice.

Key learning point: In young children with acute abdominal symptoms, an abdominal ultrasound is the preferred initial imaging modality due to its effectiveness in diagnosing conditions like intussusception and its non-invasive nature.

C) INCORRECT:

Abdominal radiographs may show indirect signs of bowel obstruction, such as air-fluid levels, but they lack specificity and sensitivity for diagnosing intussusception. They do not provide dynamic imaging or clearly identify telescoped bowel segments, making them less suitable for initial evaluation in this context.

D) INCORRECT:

Air-contrast enema serves both diagnostic and therapeutic roles in intussusception but involves radiation exposure and risk of bowel perforation. It is more appropriate after noninvasive confirmation of intussusception, rather than as an initial diagnostic test.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a 2-day history of colicky abdominal pain, intermittent vomiting, and decreased stool output. He has no significant past medical history. Physical examination reveals mild abdominal distension, diffuse tenderness without rebound, and hyperactive bowel sounds. Laboratory results show normal leukocyte count and electrolytes (see reports).

Contrast-enhanced abdominal CT: Characteristic 'target sign' in the mid-ileum, suggesting a possible intraluminal mass
Abdominal radiograph: Confirms small bowel obstruction

What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Diagnostic endoscopy to remove the suspected mass
Prolonged observation with intravenous fluid support only
Exploratory laparotomy and surgical resection of the affected bowel segment
Attempted pneumatic reduction under imaging guidance

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endoscopy is limited in accessing the mid-ileum and carries a risk of perforation, especially in small bowel obstruction. The CT findings suggest intussusception with a pathological lead point, best addressed surgically. Endoscopy may delay definitive management and is less effective in resolving mechanical obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

While intravenous fluids are essential in managing small bowel obstruction, adult intussusception often involves a pathological lead point, such as a neoplasm. The CT findings suggest a lead point, necessitating surgical intervention rather than observation, to prevent complications and address the underlying cause.

C) CORRECT:

Adult intussusception often involves a pathologic lead point, such as an intraluminal mass, which can be benign or malignant. The CT scan showing a 'target sign' suggests intussusception and a potential lead point. Surgical intervention, including exploratory laparotomy and resection, addresses the obstruction and removes the underlying lesion. This approach also allows for assessment of bowel viability and oncologic resection if necessary.

Key learning point: In adults, intussusception often requires surgical intervention due to the likelihood of a pathological lead point, making surgical resection the most appropriate procedure for complete small bowel obstruction caused by intussusception.

D) INCORRECT:

Pneumatic reduction is effective in pediatric intussusception, which is usually idiopathic. In adults, intussusception often involves a pathological lead point, such as a neoplasm. The CT findings suggest a structural lesion, making pneumatic reduction less likely to succeed and potentially risky, as it may cause bowel perforation or spread malignant cells.

questions.text: You are seeing a 3-year-old girl who is brought to the emergency department with one day of nonbilious, nonbloody vomiting, intermittent generalized abdominal pain, and one episode of nonbloody, loose stool. On initial examination, her abdominal examination is unremarkable. Thirty minutes after arrival, she becomes irritable and begins screaming in pain. On repeat examination, she pulls her legs up to her chest and has diffuse abdominal tenderness with guarding. Her diaper now contains blood-tinged, loose stool. Complete blood count, lipase, liver function tests, and urinalysis are within reference ranges. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer a proton pump inhibitor intravenously.
Consult gastroenterology for urgent upper endoscopy.
Send stool for Shiga toxin enzyme immunoassay.
Obtain CT of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous and oral contrast.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are important in the management of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). In young children, GERD typically manifests with chronic symptoms of dyspepsia, dysphagia, regurgitation, or failure to thrive, rather than the acute symptoms this patient has. A PPI may serve as a supportive measure in the setting of acute illness, but it would be a slow-acting, insufficient intervention in this patient, who has severe symptoms and requires more-urgent investigation.

B) INCORRECT:

An upper endoscopy might be considered if there is evidence of upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding. Although this patient had a positive stool test for occult blood, she is hemodynamically stable, has a normal complete blood count, and lacks clear signs of acute, upper GI bleeding such as hematemesis. Upper endoscopy is generally avoided when there is concern for an acute process requiring surgery (as in this patient); the test is reserved for evaluation of chronic symptoms that localize to the upper GI tract.

C) INCORRECT:

Infectious causes should be considered in cases of bloody diarrhea, and in those cases, stool culture and testing for Shiga toxin may be useful. However, an infectious etiology is less likely in this patient given her episodic, severe pain. The more likely diagnosis is intussusception.

D) INCORRECT:

Abdominal CT may be helpful in the diagnostic workup of acute abdominal pain. Conditions such as acute appendicitis, pancreatitis, renal disease, and hepatobiliary disease must be considered and can be evaluated by CT. However, this patient’s normal laboratory workup (complete blood count, lipase measurement, urinalysis, and liver function testing) renders those diagnoses less likely. Moreover, CT requires radiation, which is unnecessary if ultrasound is available.

E) CORRECT:

Intussusception is characterized by the telescoping of bowel onto adjacent bowel. Although it can be transient and self-resolving, persistence of this condition requires intervention, most commonly reduction via air enema. If an air enema is unsuccessful on multiple attempts or if there are complications such as bowel perforation, emergency surgical intervention is indicated. Intussusception is most common in infants and toddlers, whose inability to characterize their symptoms might delay consideration of intussusception and complicate the diagnosis. Furthermore, the clinical presentation of intussusception is variable. The commonly described intussusception triad — colicky abdominal pain, a palpable abdominal mass, and bloody stools — is not always observed. Children < 12 months of age are more likely to have grossly bloody stools than those aged 12 to 36 months of age, and the classic palpable abdominal mass is found in < 40% of patients of all ages. Presentation of intussusception may also include nonspecific symptoms such as lethargy and altered level of consciousness. The most appropriate initial diagnostic test for intussusception is abdominal ultrasound, which has excellent sensitivity (98% –100%). Among experienced radiologists, a normal abdominal ultrasound can rule out intussusception. Ultrasound is relatively inexpensive, easily accessible, and does not involve radiation.

Key learning point: The best initial diagnostic modality for intussusception is abdominal ultrasound.
questions.hint: This patient’s presentation — particularly the intermittent nature of the abdominal pain — is most consistent with intussusception. Intussusception is a common cause of acute abdominal pain in young children and the leading cause of bowel obstruction in this age group. Because it is a surgical emergency, failure to promptly diagnose and treat it can result in poor outcomes.

questions.text: You are seeing a 6-year-old boy in the emergency department who presents with acute, intermittent umbilical pain that started this morning. The pain radiates to his right lower abdomen and occurs every 15–30 minutes. He has had several episodes of nonbilious vomiting. He had a similar episode 3 months ago. On abdominal examination, there is periumbilical tenderness without palpable masses. Laboratory studies reveal anemia. Abdominal ultrasound shows a target sign in transverse section. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute appendicitis manifests with diffuse, continuous, abdominal pain migrating from the periumbilical region to the right lower quadrant, vomiting, and a “target sign” on ultrasound. However, repeated attacks of pain and the presence of anemia in this patient suggest a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Malrotation with volvulus typically manifests with acute onset of abdominal pain and bloody stools. On abdominal ultrasound, the classic feature of volvulus is a whirlpool sign (also known as “whirl sign”; referring to the twisted mesentery), which can easily be distinguished from the target sign described in this patient. Although the clinical features may be similar, a volvulus caused by malrotation of the intestines usually occurs during early infancy; it would be uncommon in a 6-year-old child.

C) CORRECT:

Recurrent episodes of intussusception should raise concern for a pathological lead point. Intussusception due to a pathological lead point should always be suspected in children > 5 years or < 3 months of age, whereas idiopathic intussusception (i.e., without an identifiable lead point) most commonly occurs in children 3 months to 5 years of age. Meckel diverticulum is the pathological lead point that most commonly causes intussusception. Meckel diverticulum may contain ectopic gastric mucosal cells that secrete gastric acid and thereby lead to irritation and ulceration of the adjacent small bowel, which can cause occult gastrointestinal bleeding and anemia.

A technetium-99m pertechnetate scan can be used to diagnose Meckel diverticulum.

Key learning point: Meckel diverticulum is the most common pathological lead point causing intussusception in children, often presenting with recurrent abdominal pain and anemia due to gastrointestinal bleeding.
Image Description:

Ultrasound abdomen (bowel; transverse plane)

Concentric alternating hyperechoic and hypoechoic rings are visible. The hyperechoic rings (green overlay) are formed by mucosa and the hypoechoic rings (red overlay) by submucosa. Together the alternating layers produce a target-like appearance (target sign; bull's eye sign).

D) INCORRECT:

Intestinal adhesions may cause bowel obstruction or act as a pathological lead point for intussusception. They usually form after previous abdominal surgery, intraabdominal inflammation, or abdominal radiotherapy, none of which is mentioned in this patient's history.

E) INCORRECT:

Intestinal polyps are the second most common pathological lead point resulting in intussusception. While intestinal polyps cannot be entirely excluded, they are not the most common cause of intussusception in this age group. This patient appears to have had chronic blood loss that resulted in anemia, suggesting a different etiology.
questions.hint: Acute onset of cyclical abdominal pain, vomiting, and a target sign on ultrasound is consistent with an episode of intussusception.

questions.text: A 14-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a 4-hour history of intermittent crying episodes that occur every 20 minutes. During the episodes, she draws her knees to her chest and appears inconsolable, but between episodes she plays normally. Her parents report one episode of vomiting. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant and high-pitched bowel sounds. After initiating IV fluids and providing analgesia, what is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Plain abdominal x-ray has low diagnostic accuracy for intussusception and not the most appropriate initial imaging modality. Although distended bowel loops may be visible, another modality provides superior diagnostic capability.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Abdominal ultrasound is the preferred initial imaging modality for suspected intussusception in children due to its high sensitivity and specificity, absence of radiation, and ability to facilitate immediate ultrasound-guided reduction when indicated. Classic findings of intussusception include the target sign on transverse view and pseudokidney sign on longitudinal view.

C) INCORRECT:

Abdominal CT is the preferred imaging modality for suspected intussusception in adults but not in children. In pediatric patients, another modality is a more appropriate next step to minimize radiation exposure while providing excellent diagnostic accuracy and therapeutic potential.

D) INCORRECT:

Although a surgical consult should be obtained for confirmed intussusception, the diagnosis should first be confirmed with imaging. Surgery is indicated for signs of bowel perforation, intestinal ischemia, or unsuccessful conservative management.

E) INCORRECT:

Image-guided enema can be used to confirm the diagnosis of intussusception if there is diagnostic uncertainty and can facilitate reduction. However, an alternative step in management should be performed first.

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to intermittent episodes of intense crying. The parents report that for the past 12 hours, the infant has had sudden spells of inconsolable crying while drawing his knees to his chest, lasting for several minutes. Between these episodes, he appears lethargic. He has had one episode of nonbilious emesis. His last bowel movement was normal. On examination, he is afebrile with a heart rate of 160/min. His abdomen is soft and nondistended, with a poorly defined, sausage-shaped mass palpable in the right upper quadrant. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial imaging study to confirm the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: Upper GI series with small bowel follow-through
CT scan of the abdomen with contrast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for intussusception. Abdominal ultrasound is the initial imaging modality of choice due to its high sensitivity and specificity and lack of ionizing radiation. The pathognomonic finding is a target sign on the transverse view, which represents the layers of the telescoped bowel. Ultrasound can also identify potential pathologic lead points, assess for vascular compromise via Doppler flow, and detect trapped fluid, which may indicate a lower likelihood of successful nonoperative reduction. Confirmation of the diagnosis with ultrasound is a prerequisite before attempting therapeutic reduction.

B) INCORRECT:

An upper gastrointestinal series is used to evaluate for other causes of pediatric vomiting and obstruction, such as malrotation with midgut volvulus or pyloric stenosis. However, this infant's presentation is typical for intussusception, making an upper gastrointestinal series an inappropriate initial test.

C) INCORRECT:

While a CT scan can diagnose intussusception, it is not the appropriate initial imaging study. It exposes the infant to significant ionizing radiation and is more expensive and time-consuming than ultrasound. CT is typically reserved for cases in which the diagnosis is uncertain after ultrasound or to evaluate for complications in atypical presentations.

D) INCORRECT:

An air or contrast enema is the primary therapeutic intervention for reducing an uncomplicated ileocolic intussusception, not the initial diagnostic study. Although it can be diagnostic by showing a filling defect, an ultrasound is first performed to confirm the diagnosis and rule out contraindications such as perforation before proceeding with this potentially curative procedure.

E) INCORRECT:

An abdominal radiograph is often obtained in infants with abdominal pain, but it is not the primary modality to diagnose intussusception. Findings may be normal or show nonspecific signs of a small bowel obstruction, such as dilated loops of bowel or a soft tissue mass. Its main utility in this setting is to rule out free air, which would indicate bowel perforation and be an absolute contraindication to a therapeutic enema.
questions.hint: This infant's presentation of paroxysmal colicky abdominal pain, lethargy, and a palpable sausage-shaped mass is consistent with intussusception.
